def.dt: :an early Jewish Christian traditionally identified as the writer of the Gospel of Mark called also John Mark
:the second Gospel in the New Testament see bible table
:a king of Cornwall, uncle of Tristram, and husband of Isolde

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English mearc boundary, march, sign; akin to Old High German marha boundary, Latin margo

def.dt: :a boundary land
:a conspicuous object serving as a guide for travelers
:something (as a line, notch, or fixed object) designed to record position
:one of the bits of leather or colored bunting placed on a sounding line at intervals
:target
:the starting line or position in a track event
:goal object
:an object of attack, ridicule, or abuse
:a victim or prospective victim of a swindle
:the point under discussion
:condition of being correct or accurate her observations are on the mark
:a standard of performance, quality, or condition :norm not feeling up to the mark lately
:sign indication gave her the necklace as a mark of his esteem
:an impression (as a scratch, scar, or stain) made on something
:a distinguishing trait or quality :characteristic the marks of an educated person
:a symbol used for identification or indication of ownership
:a cross made in place of a signature
:trademark

dt.un: used with a numeral to designate a particular model of a weapon or machine Mark II

def.dt: :a written or printed symbol (as a comma or colon)
:postmark
:a symbol used to represent a teacher's estimate of a student's work or conduct
:grade
:a figure registering a point or level reached or achieved the halfway mark in the first period of play
:record
:attention notice nothing worthy of mark
:importance distinction stands out as a person of mark
:a lasting or strong impression
:an assessment of merits :rating got high marks for honesty

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English mearcian; akin to Old High German marcōn to mark, determine the boundaries of, Old English mearc boundary

def.dt: :to fix or trace out the bounds or limits of
:to plot the course of :chart
:to set apart by or as if by a line or boundary usually used with off
:to designate as if by a mark
:to make or leave a mark on
:to furnish with natural marks wings marked with white
:to label so as to indicate price or quality
:to make notations in or on
:to make note of in writing :jot marking the date in his journal
:to indicate by a mark or symbol mark an accent
:register record
:to determine the value of by means of marks or symbols :grade mark term papers
:characterize distinguish the flamboyance that marks her style
:signalize this year marks our 50th anniversary
:to take notice of :observe mark my words
:to pick up (one's golf ball) from a putting green and substitute a marker
:to take careful notice
:to keep the time of a marching step by moving the feet alternately without advancing
:to maintain a static state of readiness the House was marking time while the Senate talked F. L. Paxson

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English marc, probably of Scandinavian origin; akin to Old Norse mǫrk mark; akin to Old English mearc sign

def.dt: :any of various old European units of weight used especially for gold and silver
:a unit equal to about eight ounces (248 grams)
:a unit of value:
:an old English unit equal to 13s 4d
:any one of various old Scandinavian or German units of value
:a unit and corresponding silver coin of the 16th century worth 1/2 taler
:deutsche mark
:the basic monetary unit of East Germany replaced in 1990 by the West German deutsche mark
:markka
:to put a lower price on
:to put a markup on
:accent 5a
:accent 8
:a symbol used to indicate musical stress
:a mark placed after a letter designating a note of music to indicate in which octave the note occurs
:a mark or device used to identify a product or service that has been certified to conform to a particular set of standards
:a fine undulation formed on the surface of work by a chattering tool
:one of a series of short curved cracks on a glaciated rock surface transverse to the glacial striae
